Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Organic Field Effect Transistor Force Sensor for Touch Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to develop a force sensitive touch surface technology that will overcome the technical shortcomings of currently available technologies. The design leverages the thin form factor, optical transmissivity, and cost advantages of organic printed electronics in a novel configuration to allow for environmentally stable, active-array touch surfaces and displays to be produced with scalable manufacturing techniques. The solution is intended to enable truly force sensitive touch that is low cost and highly sensitive. It will be operable with any object, including fingernails, gloves, and styluses, while not being susceptible to environmental factors that hinder current capacitive technologies, such as dirt and moisture. If successfully developed it will consume less power than leading technologies, and will not inherently require special materials such as glass to be used as the touch surface.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project results from its relevance to a wide array of applications, including force sensitive buttons for consumer electronics, automotive controls, and force sensitive displays for fixed and mobile devices. Two decades ago, touch technology was primarily found within ATMs and point-of-sale systems. More recently, the technology migrated to other electronic industry verticals, including one of the largest and certainly the fastest growing - smartphones and tablets. Consumer demand is driving an explosion of applications in every vertical. There is increasing demand for low cost, low power, more feature rich touch solutions. In addition, new user experience benefits such as force sensitivity are constantly being pursued, yet there is no viable solution yet on the market. Such a technology would be poised to capture significant market share from existing technologies in all of these markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project entitled “Organic Field Effect Transistor Force Sensor for Touch Surfaces” sought to develop a force sensitive solution for touch applications that overcame the technical shortcomings of currently available single touch force sensing technologies. The sensor design consisted of an engineered approach to the lack of viable piezoelectric or piezoresistive materials to implement a gray-scale pressure transducer compatible with OFET technology; and particularly, transparent OFET technology. The design would enable truly force sensitive multitouch displays that would be operable with any object - including fingernails, gloves, and styluses - while not being susceptible to environmental factors that hinder current touch technologies such as dirt and moisture.

The approach was to use a highly stable, proprietary top-gate OFET technology to amplify the response of a nano- or micro-patterned semiconductor layer. The device would produce a piezoresistive response through a geometrical change of contact area and be subsequently coupled to the OFET through a voltage divider. The pressure response of single OFETs was first characterized to serve as a baseline for further development of the transparent piezoresistive element. Characterization of the pressure response of the bi-layer gate dielectric revealed changes of capacitance density on the order of 0.4%. In contrast, individual OFETs were found to display a pressure response on the order of 5.7% at 11kPa.

Early efforts were focused on characterizing the intrinsic pressure response of OFETs instead of developing a piezoresistive layer. The response was found to display very large sample-to-sample variations, making it very difficult to conduct a systematic study of the fundamental causes behind this response. Conventional OFETs and OFETs with interdigitated electrodes were fabricated on glass and flexible substrates to investigate the possibility of amplification of the response and substrate influence, respectively. The ratio between PTAA and TIPS-pentacene was also varied to study the possible effect of pressure-sensitive percolation on the semiconductor layer.

These efforts resulted in the realization that the measured response was not reproducible and likely not intrinsic to the organic semiconductor channel. As evidence, InGaZnO thin film transistors were fabricated and found to display a similar response to the OFETs. In view of these results, efforts were redirected at developing the piezoresistive layer to implement a voltage-divider approach. This approach was validated using fixed resistor elements to study the range of resistance values and resistance changes needed to optimize the OFET output to a change of resistance. It was found that a change of resistance of around two-orders of magnitude would be needed for the pressure sensor to provide a high dynamic range. With this in mind, mixtures of PDMS with PEDOT:PSS fillers were studied in order to produce bulk material that could be coated on top of the OFETs. These mixtures proved to be very inhomogeneous due to the large surface energy between the two materials and transparency was also found hard to control.

In addition to the work towards developing a pressure sensitive OFET layer, multitouch algorithms were designed and implemented that could very efficiently calculate the location and force associated with multiple touch points from a heat map generated from a finite number of sensor elements. By doing so, the resolution of the touch device could be enhanced beyond the spacing of the individual sensor nodes into the sub-mm regime. These algorithms were simple enough to be run on a low-cost commercial MCU at rates that would significantly exceed the touch refresh rate of currently available multitouch technologies.
